bodyText:
There isn't a play button accessible to screen readers in embedded YouTube videos. This means that the previous live pairing videos are not accessible. I tested it out with Voice Over and can't access a play button at all.

title: more verbose bonfire challenge descriptions
bodyText:
At times, the bonfire challenge descriptions do not always give a clear expectation of what the test cases are looking for. The test cases are sometimes visible when the programmer tries to run a program, but not always clearly written out from a user standpoint.
Example: "Where do I belong?"
"Return the lowest index at which a value (second argument) should be inserted into a sorted array (first argument)."
The test cases that are visible after submitting code are:
"assert.equal(indexForNum, 3, '35 should be inserted at index 3');"
assert.equal(indexFor30, 2, '30 should be inserted at index 2');
While the test cases obviously work from a functionality standpoint, what is visible to the user is not always clear. What are indexforNum and then indexfor30?
The description of the problem, visible upon load, could simply add,
"[[2,4,6,8], 7] should return 3"
If the lack of verbose instructions is part of the challenge, then it doesn't need changed; on the other hand, being a bit more explicit about the spec of a particular problem seems more "real-life" and could be helpful.
I am willing to add this feature myself, but only if it doesn't conflict with the intent and purpose of the bonfire challenges. :)

title: Inconsistent dasherization
bodyText:
First: the zipline title Zipline: Stylize Stories on Camper News dasherizes as zipline:-stylize-stories-on-camper-news. Note the dash after colon. However the story on camper news AppMachine: Make an app within hours. - AppMachine dasherizes as appmachine-make-an-app-within-hours--appmachine. No dash after colon and a confusing double-dash at the end, which brings us to...
Second: one of the requirements of the zipline is to make a link to the story discussion page. In the json that http://www.freecodecamp.com/stories/hotStories returns there is a property storyLink and for the AppMachine story the value is appmachine make an app within hours appmachine.  If I were to turn all spaces into dashes I would get appmachine-make-an-app-within-hours-appmachine, which is incorrect (remember the double-dash?).
I think the only way to link back to the page from json is to dasherize the headline, which is more difficult to do and probably not intended (otherwise, why include storyLink?)
What do you think the proper dasherization algorithm is? Maybe we should just delete all punctuation, trim the string and replace all whitespace with single dashes?

Tests in Friendly Date Ranges Bonfire
bodyText:
One of the tests for that bonfire is : friendly(['2016-03-01', '2016-05-05']), which is supposed to give  : ['March 1st','May 5th, 2016'].
And another test is the same bonfire is : friendly(['2015-12-01', '2016-02-03']), which is supposed to give :
['December 1st','February 3rd'].
This doesn't make sense. If it can be inferred, based on the difference being one month apart, that it's the next year, for the second case, then it should also be possible for the first case too. March and May are one month apart, so the output should be ['March 1st','May 5th'] just like the second case.

title: Potentially misleading copy for beginners
bodyText:
The copy here seems misleading especially for those coming from no knowledge of javascript. It looks as though jQuery isn't also Javascript.

[http://www.freecodecamp.com/challenges/get-started-with-jquery]
Existing copy:


jQuery is a powerful tool for manipulating HTML elements.


It's a lot easier to use than JavaScript itself, so we'll learn it first.


Suggested copy:


jQuery is a powerful javascript framework for manipulating HTML elements.


It's a lot easier to use than plain JavaScript itself, so we'll learn it first.

title: Maintaining Streak
bodyText:
Everybody has a different pace at which we are comfortable at studying. Some challenges on the Map take longer then others, sometimes you stop and read a different source. Learning is a curve, and sometimes it can be difficult to motivate yourself. I use streaks as a motivation tool. If I am not able to complete a challenge today because I spent a day reading a book to understand a concept better, then I believe I should still get a streak. Perhaps you get one point if you logged in to the website, or perhaps you write a summary not on what you've been up to today.
Thank you for consideration.

title: Symmetric Difference Bonfire(42) description is unclear
bodyText:
Create a function that takes two or more arrays and returns an array of the symmetric difference of the provided arrays.
I initially assumed that it wanted us to sym-diff all the provided arrays at once. However, what it actually wants is for us to sym the first two, sym that with the next one and so on..
Many others have had the same confusion and I think it's worth a rewrite of the description.
Create a function that takes two or more arrays and reduces them into the symmetric difference of the provided arrays.
Like Array.prototype.reduce(), your function should sym-diff the first two arrays, then sym-diff the result with the next one, and so on.

title: When use image is broken camper news image breaks.
bodyText:
Steps to repeat.

Use twitter for signing
update twitter image


twitter breaks last image url
FCC shows default camper image for user image


post link to camper news


Camper news uses user image url, which at this point is broken


Update image url to new twitter image url


User image is updated
Camper news image is not updated, still broken.


possible solutions:

When posting link, ping user image and look for 200 code, if positive use image, else use default image. (only checks once, only slows down link posting)
When rendering camper news pull image url from user. (this would be costly and would slow down rendering)

title: Vim/Emacs/Sublime Text keybindings in Bonfires
bodyText: I was digging around the code base when I found out that you use CodeMirror as the editor for Bonfires. CodeMirror supports Vim, Emacs and Sublime Text keymaps, and since quite a big part of the user base (at least the one active in the Slack room) uses one or more of these editors, implementing them would most likely be very appreciated. I'd do it myself, but turns out the building blocks of FCC confuses the living hell out of me, so I'll come back when I'm done with all the challenges.

title: Bonfires code editor should auto-save a user's work
bodyText: It would be great if the code editor for the Bonfires auto-saved a user's work. This would prevent losing code if you accidentally close your tab, or your browser crashes. It would also make it easy to go back and review what code you used, after having completed a bonfire.

Waypoint 40: Manage Packages with NPM tweaks
bodyText:
Summary of recommendations:

Recommend changing step 11 of Waypoint 40 to drop sudo.
Recommend adding two notes on possible bugs in parts 08 and 09 of how-to-npm.

Tweak step 11

Run this command: npm install how-to-npm -g

I ran simultaneous workspaces, installing how-to-npm with and without sudo. With sudo, you needed to sudo all of the things, which shouldn't be necessary, and some things didn't work as expected even then.
(Ex.: Part 13, Outdated. npm outdated produces no result, so campers would have to guess the outdated package or ask how-to-npm to reveal the answer.)
Without sudo nearly everything works as expected with two minor bugs:
Notes to be added

In part 08 Publish, how-to-npm forgot about me and npm adduser was of no use. But if you return to part 02 and run npm adduser again (or its alias 'npm login') and verify, then return to part 08, you can proceed.
In part 09 Version, npm version is supposed to automatically update your package.json but it doesnt. You have to manually edit the version number in your package.json before you can verify and continue.

Aside from that, everything else works, and you don't have to sudo anything.
